Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 49406-002 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2017 
 
 
 
Supporting Developing Member Countries in 
Implementing ADB’s Second-Generation 
Procurement Reforms 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
DMC  –  developing member country 
OSMFD  –  Operations Services and Financial Management Department 
TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

Director General  Risa Zhijia Teng, Operations Services and Financial Management 
Department (OSFMD)

Juliet F. Vanta, Associate Operations Analyst, OSFMD

territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the implementation of 
the new procurement framework of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) through outreach efforts, 
capacity building, and training of executing agencies and implementing agencies in ADB’s 
developing member countries (DMCs). It will build upon the work of ADB’s TA for Enhancing 
Procurement Performance of Developing Member Countries in ADB Projects,1 which supported 
the development of the procurement policy and regulations for ADB borrowers. 
 
2.  The heads of departments endorsed this follow-up TA as corporate priority TA for 2017 
on 11 November 2016.2
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Procurement reforms were initiated in 2014 through the midterm review action plan3 of 
Strategy 2020 to strengthen ADB’s operational efficiency and effectiveness.4 This included the 
implementation of a 10-point procurement action plan that aimed to (i) improve ADB’s business 
processes, (ii) increase ADB responsiveness and engagement, and (iii) more effectively respond 
to evolving changes of global procurement practices. While the application of these actions 
produced encouraging results, the overall procurement time taken by the project executing and 
implementing agencies of DMCs and ADB still remained high, and ADB was also seen as 
emphasizing  procedural  compliance  in  a  one-size-fits-all  fashion.  Consequently,  deeper 
procurement reforms were needed to achieve a better, faster, and more effective procurement 
system.  To  respond  to  such  concerns,  an  interdepartmental  procurement  reform  steering 
committee and several working groups were formed in early 2016 to review and suggest ways to 
further enhance ADB’s procurement processes and procedures. A survey among ADB clients 
was also conducted, in addition to seeking inputs from internal ADB working groups. The result 
was a new procurement framework5 approved by the ADB Board of Directors on 12 April 2017. 
 
4.  ADB’s second-generation procurement reforms introduced under the new framework are 
guided by two documents: the Procurement Policy and the Procurement Regulations for ADB 
Borrowers. The Procurement Policy, approved by the ADB Board of Directors, includes two new 
core procurement principles—quality and value for money—in addition to economy, efficiency, 
fairness,  and  transparency.  These  principles  permit  the  introduction  of  fit-for-purpose 
procurement methods to support, among others, procurement of high-level technologies; and, 
together  with  an  enhanced  complaint-handling  mechanism,  are  aimed  at  addressing 
procurement-related  complaints  in  a  timely  manner  with  transparency  and  fairness.  The 
Procurement  Policy  also  introduces  alternative  procurement  arrangements  to  allow  the 
application  of  the  procurement  rules  and  procedures  of  other  development  agencies  and 
accredited agencies in DMCs. The Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers approved by the 
ADB  Management  contain  operational  procedures  for  ADB  borrowers  to  implement  the 
Procurement Policy. 
 
5.  When the procurement framework became effective on 1 July 2017, an implementation 
action plan was formulated to guide and help monitor the framework’s rollout to executing 
 
1 ADB. 2015. Enhancing Procurement Performance of Developing Member Countries in ADB Projects. Manila. 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 11 December 2017. 
3 ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. Manila. 
4 ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
5 ADB. 2017. Improving ADB Project Performance through Procurement Reforms. Manila.

2 
 
agencies and implementing agencies. The plan identifies specific actions to be taken along with 
executing  agencies  and  implementing  agencies  focusing  on  three  areas  for  improvement: 
reducing total procurement time, improving quality, and developing a robust and effective delivery 
system. The implementation of these actions requires extensive support to ADB’s DMCs to 
successfully adopt and implement the new framework. Providing this support will need significant 
outreach efforts, training of executing and implementing agencies staff, as well as capacity 
building throughout the implementation. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: effective and sustainable execution of ADB’s 
procurement reforms through strengthened procurement capacity.6 The TA will have the following 
outcome: enhanced procurement-related decision making by DMCs.7
 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Capacity of executing and implementing agencies to implement ADB’s 
second-generation procurement reforms enhanced. The training programs under the TA will 
be designed to upgrade the skills of executing and implementing agencies’ staff and improve their 
understanding of the procurement procedures introduced by the new framework. Participants will 
be acquainted with ADB’s core procurement principles (with emphasis on value for money and 
quality), usage of open competitive bidding, identification and resolution of abnormally low bids, 
application  of  a  standstill  period,  and  the  risk-based  oversight  function  for  the  review  of 
procurement transactions by ADB. The training programs will also guide the attendees on the 
complaint-handling mechanisms; special approaches related to public–private partnerships and 
fragile  or  conflict-affected  situations;  and  methods  of  adopting  and  contracting  high-level 
technology solutions in areas such as climate change, smart grids, renewable energy, toll or 
ticketing systems, mass transit, and remote-sensing technology, to name a few.8 To the extent 
practical, training for executing and implementing agencies will be coordinated with the respective 
World Bank country teams and may be jointly organized to improve efficiency and effectiveness. 
Orientation seminars will also be organized for key stakeholders, such as regulators and oversight 
bodies, and for the private sector in DMCs to make the transition to the new procurement 
framework seamless. Sector-, project-, or topic-specific procurement clinics will also be provided 
as needed. Train-the-trainer-type procurement clinics may also be arranged to train officials from 
executing agencies that handle high volume of procurement. 
 
8.  Output  2:  Procurement  procedures,  systems  of,  and/or  arrangements  with 
executing  agencies  or  cofinanciers  enhanced.  A  key  feature  of  the  new  procurement 
framework is ADB’s ability to accept alternative procurement arrangements. The TA will support 
assessments of agency procurement systems proposed by borrowers in ADB-financed projects. 
Executing  agencies  with  robust  systems  and  procurement  capacity  will  be  evaluated  and 
accredited. The identification of potential executing agencies will be undertaken in consultation 
with ADB regional departments and borrowers. The TA will also appraise the procurement 
arrangements of ADB’s cofinanciers and other financing partners with a view to accepting the use 
of these on cofinanced projects to lower the transaction costs of borrowers through mutual 
 
6 Defined by the technical assistance. 
7 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
8 ADB. 2017. ADB Establishes Fund to Promote High-Level Technology – Japan First Donor. News release. 6 May.

3 
 
reliance. As for fragile or conflict-affected situations or those involving high-level technology, the 
TA will present opportunities for these kinds of scenarios to be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. 
The TA will also take into account the ongoing initiatives led by ADB’s regional departments on 
how to deal with these situations to ensure synergy. 
 
9.  Output 3: Effective knowledge management. The successful dissemination of ADB’s 
second-generation procurement reforms will rely not only on the information drive and the various 
capacity-building activities that executing and implementing agencies will benefit from, but also 
on the knowledge management products that will be generated. Information kits will be distributed 
to orientation seminars and training workshops, and will contain useful data to provide basic 
information about the new procurement framework. Case studies coming from the sector-, or 
project-, or topic-specific workshops will be compiled and will be made available in print and online 
forms for project staff, both from ADB and executing and implementing agencies, to benefit from 
the discussions by workshop attendees. Where necessary, reading materials will be translated 
into the languages that executing and implementing agencies have requested to help them better 
understand and appreciate the concepts, so that they can be applied properly in ADB-financed 
projects. In addition, e-learning modules will be available on ADB’s website for executing and 
implementing agencies and those who are interested in ADB’s new procurement framework. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6 and TASF-other sources). The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  ADB will administer the TA. Procurement Division 1 of ADB’s Operations Services and 
Financial Management Department (OSFMD) will carry out TA activities and will select, supervise, 
and  evaluate  consultants  under  the  direction  and  implementation  oversight  of  OSFMD 
management.9 The division will coordinate closely with other OSFMD divisions, ADB operation 
units (regional departments and resident mission offices), and other sector and thematic groups 
to ensure that the benefits of ADB’s new procurement framework are optimized. Where the need 
arises, OSFMD procurement specialists will participate in orientation seminars and training 
workshops as resource persons. 
 
12.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table below:

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
13.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following ADB’s Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or  staff  instructions.  10  Consultants  must  have  strong  expertise  in  public  procurement, 
knowledge  about  procurement  in  the  private  sector,  and  exposure  to  good  international 
procurement practices. Familiarity with procurement systems of multilateral development banks 
and their operations is a must. The consulting firm must be extensively involved in procurement 
training and capacity building provided to the public sector. Individual consultants, depending on 
the specific position, must have expertise and experience in using procurement assessment 
tools11 and be familiar with certification and accreditation programs; must demonstrate up-to-date 
knowledge and experience in special procurement arrangements in fragile or conflict-affected 
situations  or  those  involving  high-level  technology;  or  must  have  the  relevant  educational 
background  and  working  experience  in  development  of  e-learning  modules.  One  contract 
package with an estimated value of $1,000,000 will be used to recruit a firm through the quality- 
and  cost-based selection method  (with  a quality–cost  ratio of  90:10). About five  individual 
consultants will be recruited using the individual consultant selection method, with an estimated 
value of $350,000. Each contract package will be a time-based contract. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting  Developing  Member  Countries  in  Implementing  ADB’s  Second-Generation 
Procurement Reforms, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
10 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
11 Such as the methodology for assessing procurement systems tool, the World Bank’s country procurement 
assessment report tool, the World Bank’s alternative procurement arrangements assessment tool, or ADB’s country, 
sector, or agency procurement assessment tool.

6  Appendix 1 
 
 
Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.  Capacity of executing and implementing agencies to implement the new ADB procurement 
reforms enhanced 
1.1 Mobilize consultants by 2018. 
1.2 Procurement specialists coordinate with regional departments and DMCs to identify target executing 
and implementing agencies, and training participants from Q2 2018 to Q3 2019. 
1.3 Consultants prepare training materials on the new procurement policy in coordination with OSFMD 
procurement specialists by Q3 2018. 
1.4 Consultants conduct orientation seminars by Q4 2018. 
1.5 Consultants conduct training workshops to executing and implementing agencies by Q1 2020. 
 
2.  Procurement procedures, systems of, and/or arrangements with executing agencies or 
cofinanciers enhanced 
2.1 In consultation with OSFMD procurement specialists and ADB regional departments, consultants 
identify candidate projects for an APA from Q2 2018 to Q4 2019. 
2.2 Consultants assess agency procurement systems of DMCs and recommend whether an APA can be 
applied by Q1 2020. 
2.3 Consultants assess procurement systems of cofinanciers or other financing partners and recommend 
whether an APA can be applied by Q1 2020. 
2.3 Consultants evaluate and make recommendations on procurement systems and arrangements 
dealing with HLT and FCAS by Q4 2019. 
 
3. Effective knowledge management generated 
3.1 Consultants transfer all training materials and tool kits developed under the TA to OSFMD for future 
use. 
Inputs 
Asian Development Bank: Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6 and TASF-other sources)
